section.title: Common Javascript Elements and Concepts
section.text: The 'document' object represents the HTML5 document object. This gives you access to all of the elements found in the file. These are known as the Document Object Model (DOM) which we will later discuss how to get elements and attributes for these objects.
Similar to the concept of a class object, DOM objects have attributes and methods which can be called. For example if we want to write a line to the document, the method 'writeln()' can be called.

Objects have attributes that can be set or simply just to get the value of an attribute. You can call the method '.setattribute(...)' or to modify/get CSS attributes you can directly set them. For example if you want to hide an element you can do the following

You can mix and match single quotes ' with double quotes " and they should work the same in any case. What is useful is when you want to display either single/ double quotes to the user. You should then nest the quotes you wish to show in the opposing quotes.

The window object can be thought of as the browser window. You can invoke an alert dialog (a), create a function that will be called when the window loads (b), and even get a user's input from a window prompt (c). We will discuss this syntax later in the tutorial.
section.definition: The '+' symbol can be used to concatinate strings as well as add numbers. You must be careful with this and not confuse concatinating string with adding numbers. Look at the following as an example, where y = 5. y + 2 =" + y + 2 Expected: "y + 2 = 7" Result: "y + 2 = 52" This is the wrong result since we mixed string with integer values. We need to specify exactly that we want to add two integers by grouping them within brackets. This will add (y + 2) as ints then concat them with the "y + 2 =" string. y + 2 =" + (y + 2) Result: "y + 2 = 7"

Typically it is good enough to compare two objects/values with a == a or a != b. But in Javascript the following condition would also return true, "72" == 72, even though one is a string and another is an integer. To strictly compare you must use '===' or '!=='

section.title1: There are a few main objects and methods that would be excellent to understand as an introduction to Javascript. Before listing some of them, it should be noted that Javascript behaves similarly to python in that it does not explicitly define an element's/object's type. You do not need to specifiy the parameter type (ie. function(nameOfParam){} rather than function(int name){}) or need to specifying one for a variable. You can simply give the type 'var' for every variable you create (similar to the capabilities of C#). With that in mind, here is a list of some common Javascript knowledge:
